The recommended return-to-learn plan will be released on Thursday, August 6th. It will include information on the two choices - in-person and online. We are planning for our online instruction to be provided by our own teachers so that it will follow the same curriculum as in-person instruction. On Sunday, August 9th, we will hold a Town Hall Meeting at 6:30 p.m. through a virtual platform (Zoom). More details on how to access this meeting will be forthcoming with the release of the return-to-learn plan.

During a time of high anxiety and many questions, schools have been faced with difficult decisions and increased need for planning. At SJPS, we have worked to include the voices of many of our stakeholders as well as review guidance documents for safe reopening of schools. We appreciate your patience during this time.

We would like to Congratulate one of St. Johns High School Teachers, Alexandria Svoboda, for receiving the Rising Star Award.

The award is presented each year at the FCSEM (Family and Consumer Science Educators of Michigan) conference. This award is given to up and coming FCS teachers who are in their first 5 years of teaching. Candidates must be a current FCS teacher in a school in Michigan and exhibit new and creative ways to enhance their FCS program and leave a positive, lasting impressions on students/community.

Delane Boog - 19 years

Heather Dedyne - 22 years
Cindy Klaus - 30 years
Mike Watson - 8 years
Michelle Wells - 25 years

A message from our local Health Department........

Southeast Michigan is experiencing a measles outbreak. While there are no cases in our area yet, the Mid-Michigan District Health Department is urging residents to make sure they and their children have been vaccinated.

Measles is a highly contagious virus that spreads through the air when an infected person breathes, coughs or sneezes. The virus can live up to two hours in the air. Measles is so contagious that if someone has it, nearly everyone close to that person will also get the disease unless they have been vaccinated or are immune. A person is considered immune if they have had the disease, been vaccinated or born before 1957.

SJPS teachers and administration have been working to find ways to better support our students and families. Over the past couple years we have participated in a "Poverty Simulation" activity as well as learned ways to support students who are affected by trauma.

Below is an opportunity to better understand the realities of poverty. Parents are encouraged to participate with their child, if they are of middle or high school age.

The Clinton Substance Abuse Prevention Coalition is hosting a Community Action Poverty Simulation on Saturday, February 9th from 9 - Noon at the First Baptist Church in St. Johns (512 S Whittemore St, St Johns).

This learning tool has been created as a way to help people understand the realities of poverty in our community. During the simulation, participants role-play the lives of low-income families. It is a free and unique opportunity to share this simulation with your children to raise awareness about poverty and homelessness in our community.

Registration is required at https://bit.ly/2DCNd2U.
